titleSet.title: Nehru With The Tricolour And The Map of India

description-en: In this poster from the Empire Calender Manufacturing Co. Jawaharlal Nehru can be seen above a map of all the states of India. The map also shows Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Burma and Buthan. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The map of Pakistan shown here offers more place-names than generally shown in such prints. It possibly dates to sometime after March 1948 when the former princely states in or adjacent to its territory had acceded, including places such as Chitral (at its northern end, February 1948), Bahawalpur (October 1947), Khairpur (October 1947), and the Baluchi states of Maksran, Las Bela and Kharan (March 1948) that are specifically named here (Wilcox, Wayne. 1963. Pakistan: The Consolidation of a Nation. New York: Columbia University Press, p. 82). As in all maps of the subcontinent produced in India, the parts of Kashmir claimed by Pakistan in late October (Poonch and Gilgit) are still shown as part of Indian national territory, and of the state of Jammu and Kashmir. Also worth noting is the appearance of the word West Punjab and East Bengal in the map across the territory marked “Pakistan,” suggesting their connection with territories in India. Finally, the naming of the Rajputana as Rajasthan points to a date after March 1948 for the map of India in this print. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This print may not be as benign as they look on first appearances: It shows the newly-delineated map of India in the company of Jawaharlal Nehru, shown with a big smile and in profile. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The most striking aspect of both prints possibly is the Indian tricolor flying triumphantly over the nation’s territory, the staff bearing it firmly planted on Kashmir. By late 1947, although the erstwhile princely state of Kashmir had agreed in an emergency maneuver to join India (through the strategic interventions and overtures primarily of Nehru), parts of its western territory had been claimed by neighbouring Pakistan after the first of the many wars and skirmishes had ended in the stalemate that endures more or less to this day. Since that time, official maps of India subsume the entirety of Kashmir, disavowing the Line of Control (LOC), the de facto border that separates Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir from Pakistan-administered Azad Kashmir and the Northern Areas. On the eastern side as well, Aksai Chin remains another no-man’s land, claimed since the 1950s by both India and China, a claim over which they went to war in 1962: here as well, a so-called Line of Actual Control constitutes the de facto border which state cartography ignores. International maps showing otherwise are stamped with the statuary comment, “The external boundaries of India as depicted on this map are neither correct nor authentic.” (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: As I discuss in another essay, barefoot mapmakers deal with the “problem” of Kashmir in numerous ingenious ways, but in such “pedagogic” productions of the bazaar from around the late 1940s and early 1950s, they basically follow the terms laid down by official and state cartography, and even more resolutely claim Kashmir for India through the presence of the Indian flag and the familiar face of Nehru. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
